title: Spain on the brink of passing law to allow gay marriage
comment:
Don't know if you've read this before already, but the interpretations of the Hebrew texts for Genesis Ch 19 have been seen buy many to have been deliberately mistranslated by the homophobic church leaders back in the day.
Two examples:Gen 19:4 often translated as - 'the men of the city, even the men of Sodom, compassed the house round, both old and young, all the poeple from every quarter'.
However, the Hebrew word transliterated as "anshei" was translated above as 'men', when it is ambiguous and can refer to people, including women and children. This seems to have been an attempt to make the mob all-male.
The second is the next verse Gen 19:5 often translated as 'They called to Lot, 'Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so that we can have sex with them.' 
Here the Hebrew word transliterated as "ya,da" is translated as 'to have sex', when it is ambiguos and can mean 'to know'.
Now considering that we already have a description earlier in Genesis as 'a tiny fortress in the barren wasteland south of the Dead Sea. The only strangers the people of Sodom ever saw were enemy tribes who wanted to destroyand take over their valuable fortress and the trade routes it protected', doesn't it seeem more likely that if some strangers appeared in Sodom, the entire town, not just the men, would want to know who they were (in case they were hostile - as many of the strangers in Sodom were) than to gang rape them?
The story of Sodom and Gomorra seems to this reader as a grossly and deliberately misinterpreted Bible passage designed to support unfounded homophobia.

Apparently the UK passed a law allowing same sex partners to "marry" last year, which comes into effect in December this year (Civil Partnership Act 2004). It appears to be equivalent to marriage in all but name. It created so little interest in the general population that I hadn't even heard about until I went looking for more info about the Spanish story!
Apparently Germany, Portugal and France (plus the usual suspects: Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Netherlands and Belgium) are all moving toward or already allow same sex unions. Looks like Europe is quietly adapting to the realities of the modern world whilst the USA tears itself apart over the issue yet again...

title: Spain on the brink of passing law to allow gay marriage
comment:
UK Civil Partnerships are not identical to marriage. There are a few small differences (and a heck of a lot more pages for the law books) because CPs are an entirely new entity. Most of the differences are minor, though I, and quite a few gay people in the UK, find one particularly insulting. CPs CANNOT have any religious component. Unlike heterosexual marriages which can be "completed" in a church by having someone "proclaim" them, CPs take effect upon the second signature, have no "proclamation" requirement, and cannot be "performed" in a church (though I guess nothing stops people from signing a document in a church).
It's a sop to the religious right and has quite a few religious folks angry that the government is seeking to dictate what can and cannot happen in a church.
more details:
http://www.womenandequalityunit.gov.uk/lgbt/faq.htm
http://www.pinkweddings.biz/thelaw.htm#b
http://www.equalitycoalition.org/pressrelease.asp?ID=4
Well, we have our head in the sand in more ways than one.

I've never been to Spain, but I have been to Portugal. It is one of the few truly old-world countries in Europe left and is quite conservative--predominantly Catholic by far.
It's a neat place and the people there are very warm and 'laid-back.' They've managed to hold on to their cultural roots and hold off against American trendiness, wanton sexual advertising and lack of modesty, violence, and out-of-control capitalism more than many of the other countries in Europe. On the other extreme, Amsterdam is probably the worst in this regard.
